Name: Myclobutanil
Description: 2-(4-chlorophenyl)-2-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)hexanenitrile is a nitrile that is hexanenitrile substituted at the 2-position by p-chlorophenyl and (1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)methyl groups. It is a nitrile, a member of triazoles and a member of monochlorobenzenes.

plant_translocations.content: Based on the original material of 14C2-labeled Ba14CO3, 14C2-labeled 1,2,4-triazole was synthesized through a 4-step reaction process. The radioactive strength, specific activity, radiochemical purity, and radiochemical yield were 5.8131 mCi, 15.5347 μCi/mg, more than 99%, and 84.21%, respectively. Following methods reported for synthesizing myclobutanil, 14C2-labeled myclobutanil was produced from 4-chlorophenylacetonitrile through substitution and condensation. Its radioactive strength, specific activity, radiochemical purity, and radiochemical yield were 0.5566 mCi, 2.53 μCi/mg, more than 96%, and 85.4%, respectively. The uptake, translocation, and distribution of 14C2-myclobutanil in wheat seedlings at the 2-3 leaf stage were studied using radioactive tracing experiments. The results showed that radioactivity in the treated wheat roots decreased from 59.88% to 24.87%, while the accumulation of radioactivity in the stem base and leaves increased from 14.18% and 1.19% to 19.47% and 33.75%, respectively, after dipping the roots into 14C2-myclobutanil solution for 6-120 hours. 14C2-myclobutanil was readily absorbed and translocated upwards to the top of wheat seedlings. The distribution and accumulation of 14C2-myclobutanil in wheat leaves were positively correlated with the treatment time of root dipping, showing a steady increase in radioactivity from 2.94 × 10-6 μCi at 6 hours to 322.72 × 10-6 μCi at 120 hours. Autoradiograph experiments indicated that 14C2-myclobutanil could be absorbed and distributed throughout the whole seedling at 120 hours after treating the roots.
plant_translocations.reference: Xi-li, L. I. U., Shuang, L. U. O., Jun, Y. A. N. G., Can-xian, M. U., & Jian-qiang, L. I. (2008). Synthesis of 14C-Labelled Myclobutanil and the Corroboration of its Uptake and Translocation in Wheat Seedling. Chinese Journal of Pesticide Science, 10(1), 23-27.

method.Plant Growth Condition: The seedlings were cultured in test tubes, 10 seedlings per tube, with a total of 2 groups.
method.Chemical Preparation: An aqueous solution of 14C-azoxystrobin was prepared with a specific activity of 1.5 μCi/mL.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: The roots of wheat seedlings were soaked in 8 mL of the aqueous solution containing 1.5 μCi/mL of 14C-azoxystrobin and cultured at 20±2°C for 6, 8, 12, 24, 48, 72, 96, and 120 hours, respectively.
method.Other Information: There were 8 replicates for each treatment time, with a total of 2 groups of replicates. After treatment, the plants were washed with water, 75% ethanol, and distilled water, and then oven-dried at 50°C for 72 hours for further analysis. This experiment used wheat seedlings as the test material, with 14C-azoxystrobin applied via root soaking. Different treatment time points were set, with sufficient replicates at each time point, to study the absorption and translocation behavior of 14C-azoxystrobin in wheat seedlings.
